dublinCore.dc:title: 110 HR 5830 IH: American Genetic Privacy Act of 2023
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Burchett introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To prohibit commercial DNA testing services from disclosing the genetic information of United States nationals to foreign entities, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the American Genetic Privacy Act of 2023.

section.header: Prohibition on disclosing genetic information to China

subsection.text: A commercial DNA testing service may not disclose the genetic information of any individual, or any aggregate of such information, to the People’s Republic of China, or to any entity under the influence, control, or ownership of the People’s Republic of China.

paragraph.header: Unfair or deceptive acts or practices
paragraph.text: A violation of this section shall be treated as a violation of a regulation under section 18(a)(1)(B) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. 57a(a)(1)(B)) regarding unfair or deceptive acts or practices.

The Federal Trade Commission shall enforce this section in the same manner, by the same means, and with the same jurisdiction, powers, and duties as though all applicable terms and provisions of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. 41 et seq.) were incorporated into and made part of this section. Any person who violates this section shall be subject to the penalties and entitled to the privileges and immunities provided in the Federal Trade Commission Act.
The term commercial DNA testing service means any person that provides genealogical or ancestry-related information based on an individual’s DNA.
The term genetic information means, with respect to any individual, information about such individual’s genetic tests.
The term genetic test has the meaning given such term by section 201 of the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act of 2008 (Public Law 110–233; 42 U.S.C. 2000ff).
